summary: The urine is processed onboard the International Space Station (ISS) by the Water Recovery System (WRS) The urine and humidity condensate are processed by the WRS . While some means of microbial control are in place .
The U.S. Water Recovery System (WRS) was launched to the ISS in 2008 . The WRS consists of the Urine Processor Assembly (UPA) and the Water Processor Assembly .

The persistence of biofilms can result in corrosion, materials degradation, and a failed water system . The wastewater tank likely contains a thriving microbial community, but low diversity is noted upon ground evaluation . The microbial profiles are determined after return of samples to Earth .

The water is held to stringent acceptability limits: 50 colony forming units (CFU/mL) for total bacteria and no detectable coliforms per 100 mL . There has never been a true positive coliform detected .
The samples were filtered using a Milliflex system with a Reasoner's 2A (R2A) agar cassette and a Sabouraud dextrose with chloramphenicol (SABC) cassette
Bacterial isolates were subcultured onto fresh R2A plates and incubated at 35 °C for 24–48 h.h. Data has been deposited in the European Nucleotide Archive (ENA) under accession number PRJEB58840 .
Guppy (version 4.3.4) has a minimum quality score of 7 and minimum barcode score of 40.4 .
Sample dehydration was performed with serial rinses using freshly prepared ethanol (200 proof, Sigma-Aldrich) in filtered, sterile Milli-Q water .

Bacterial isolates were cultured on R2A media (Hardy Diagnostics) and incubated for at least 24 h at 35 °C . After each incubation period, washing, tapping, and dissociation of the biofilms was performed . Images were acquired at 10 kV in back scatter electron mode at a pressure of ∼1.3 Torr .
The Burkholderia fungorum is a form of form of a genus of species . Burkholdia is a type of genus that has been called "Burkholdia" Burkholdaria fungorums .
Purge line (UPA115' Flex line 96 M 12561-100) is a UPA115-Flex line .

Culture-independent, 16S nanopore-generated microbial profiles . Genome summary metrics range from 3.8 to 9.7 million base pairs with 3–20 contigs . Isolates 3.1, 4.2, 44.3, and 4.5 were identified to B. contaminans, with an ANI 95.6 and 99.9 . P. fungorum pangenome analysis had 9,804 unique gene clusters across the 10 NCBI reference genomes and the two isolates: 3.3 and 4.1 . Of these unique gene . clusters, 2,314 did not have a known function from the PGAP annotations .
gal-bacterial biofilm formation (as also noted in higher magnification J – L) within the UPA115 flex line .
Isolates 3.1, 3.2, 4.3 and 4.2 demonstrated pronounced biofilm formation as compared to the control at 24 h .

Bacteria in B. contaminans generate protective antifungal compounds that were noted within the genomes . Of interest were biosynthetic gene clusters associated with the secondary metabolites occidiofungin and pyrrolnitrin .

Bacterial-fungal interaction between UPA flex line bacterial isolates and fungal growth media (R2A, PDA and SABC) at two temperatures (25 °C and 35°C) and three growth media was studied . Hemolytic potential was also assessed .  The growth diameter of <em>A. falvus did not change between the temperatures for R2A and PDA media, but more growth was noted on SABC at 35 °C . <em >B. contaminans expressed the highest antifungal capability at both temperatures and on all media assessed .

The WRS has been providing potable water to astronauts onboard the ISS since 2009 . This work represents the first investigation into the unique community that inhabits the UPA . Pyochelin biosynthesis cluster was observed in the <em>B. contaminans <em > 3.1, 3.2, 4.2 and 4.5 genomes and ornibactin gene cluster  ESEM imaging of water from the water from flex lines and biofilm potential of the recovered isolates demonstrated that these hoses are novel areas for fungal-bacterial biofilm growth . The flex lines, as well as other areas within the UPA, are ideal candidate areas to investigate horizontal gene transfer .

Urine treatment on the international space station: current practice and novel approaches . The study was published in the Proceedings of the 49th international conference on environmental systems . The authors also discuss the status of the regenerative ECLSS water recovery system .  Using real-time culture-independent micro-profiling on board the International Space Station . Using nanopore sequencing, scientists used to identify microbes from the station .
